head.title: Hot Town, Summer in the City, Still Looking for a Shadow

hedline.hl1: Hot Town, Summer in the City, Still Looking for a Shadow

block.p: Your July 11 photo spread showing people seeking respite from the heat at water's edge may be appealing to anyone spending these torrid days in New York's concrete canyons, but there is another way for city dwellers to enjoy a bit of relief.

Your July 11 photo spread showing people seeking respite from the heat at water's edge may be appealing to anyone spending these torrid days in New York's concrete canyons, but there is another way for city dwellers to enjoy a bit of relief.
Street trees are the answer. They offer a welcome oasis during these sweltering days, bestowing various beneficial effects:
* Trees offer cool, protective shade from the sun's hot rays.
* Their leaves flutter in the breeze, giving us the awareness of refreshing, moving air.
* Trees give off oxygen and take in carbon dioxide, to help purify the sultry air.
* Trees are green, a cool color providing a psychological lift.

So these hardy trees that survive despite the polluted environment of the city also take the edge off summer's heat. It may only be a state of mind, but thinking cool can be part of one's survival kit during these dog days. MAURICE BLEIFELD Chairman, Roosevelt I. Tree Board New York, July 13, 1994
